column8: The game is relaxing and enjoyable, perfect for those who love interior design and decorating.
column9: The snapping and placement mechanics are frustrating and inaccurate.

column8: The game has a lot of potential and is expected to improve with future updates.
column9: The game has numerous bugs and crashes frequently.

column8: There are some bugs and optimization issues, but they are manageable and expected in early access.
column9: The game is not optimized well, leading to performance issues.

column8: The game offers a variety of customization options for furniture and room design.
column9: There is a lack of customization options for furniture and room dimensions.

column8: The story mode includes interesting puzzles and tasks that keep the gameplay fresh.
column9: The controls and user interface are not intuitive or user-friendly.

column8: The sandbox mode allows for creative freedom and extensive customization.
column9: The game feels incomplete and lacks content.

column8: The graphics and lighting are aesthetically pleasing and add to the overall experience.
column9: The story mode and mini-games are not engaging or fun.

column8: The game is compared favorably to other interior design games like The Sims and House Flipper.
column9: The game is not suitable for realistic room planning due to restrictive mechanics.

column8: Players appreciate the ability to mod and the potential for future content through updates.
column9: The graphics and visual design are not appealing to many players.

column8: Some players have experienced issues with controls and UI, but overall find the game intuitive and fun.
column9: The game has potential but needs significant updates and improvements.

column9: Ascending Inferno is a challenging game, but it's also rewarding. You fail, you learn, and when you finally get it done, the feeling of accomplishment is incredible. The art and music are atmospheric, and you'll want to try again and again, just one more time. If you enjoy a skill-based challenge, this is definitely for you.

column9: A mountain climbing game where you kick a ball up and up to reach the summit. It was recently translated into Japanese, and it's of high quality. The story is well-crafted and well worth watching, even though it's a mountain climbing game. It was fun, but the ball's behavior was a bit erratic. There were many parts where I couldn't quite understand why it was being dropped into the abyss. If you do play it, I highly recommend playing in checkpoint mode, where you can steadily progress upwards.

column8:
A BRUTAL Climb, Worth Every Step

Ascending Inferno isnâ€™t just a game â€“ itâ€™s an experience. From the very first level, it throws you headfirst into a gauntlet of challenges that test your patience, skill, and determination. But with every failure comes a deeper understanding, and with every hard-fought victory, an overwhelming sense of satisfaction. The difficulty is real, but so is the reward.

What truly elevates this game (pun intended) is its incredible storytelling. Thereâ€™s a depth to the narrative that makes the climb feel meaningful â€“ not just for progressionâ€™s sake, but because you're fighting for something. Itâ€™s rare to see this level of emotion tied to a platformer, but Ascending Inferno pulls it off with flair.

Visually, the game is absolutely stunning. Each biome introduces a completely fresh atmosphere â€“ from the first level to the very last â€“ and the attention to detail is unmatched. There are so many small, handcrafted touches scattered throughout the world that you canâ€™t help but pause and admire, even in the middle of chaos.

Whether itâ€™s the satisfying gameplay loop, the rich story, or the jaw-dropping art direction, Ascending Inferno nails it on every front. If youâ€™re looking for a game that challenges you, rewards you, and leaves a lasting impact â€“ this is it.

column8: The game is so based. Genuinely, I went into this thinking "oh its a rage game, probably not gonna be my thing" I was so so wrong! Somehow they've managed to make this game both challenging and satisfying to play at the same time, to where even when I fall about a million times, I still have an immense amount of fun in the process, because simply just running around and kicking the ball is fun on its own. The game by its design constantly encourages you to improve by repetition until you've mastered a certain area, and I cant stress how rewarding it is seeing the progress you make, and especially when you FINALLY do that one kick that or jump that's been giving you hell. Overall, definitely one of my new favourite games and worth checking out!

column8: Ascending Inferno is surprisingly addictive, effortlessly keeping you engaged for hours. The gameâ€™s unforgiving nature may feel punishing at first, but it rewards perseveranceâ€”youâ€™ll quickly notice yourself improving with every failure. While the inconsistent physics can occasionally frustrate, they add a unique layer of challenge fitting for the rage genre. In my two hours with the game, I only scratched the surface of its world, but its distinct charm, compelling story, and striking visuals left me eager to dive deeper.
column9: Ascending Inferno is surprisingly addictive, effortlessly keeping you engaged for hours. column8: Really had fun with this game. Ascending each circle of hell really felt great and ultimately ascending all of inferno felt better. The added twist of having to "carry" a ball with you all the way differentiates this game from others like it. Also, personally, I found falling and having to climb back up less punishing than "getting over it" for example, but maybe it's just because this wasn't my first game I played in the genre

column8:
Ascending Inferno is a cool video game that invites me to play it and then kicks me in the balls

At the time of writing Iâ€™ve beaten Limbo and gotten halfway through Lust

Each level of hell has its own distinct style and visual story to tell. There is so much wondrously morbid creativity and imaginative design proudly on display. The art direction is on point. Each asset is placed with narrative meaning rewarding players willing to stop and smell the roses. Hell feels like a living breathing place that I want to spend more time exploring.

The Shader Authoring and VFX are extremely impressive there's so many beautiful technical marvels hidden in this game. I particularly love the screen space reflection on the glass windows.

Secret rooms are like a respite in this game. Similar to a safe room in Resident Evil. I feel relieved when i accidently screw up a kick and then instead of getting punished I get rewarded with a story beat instead. Never seen this done in a video game and it suits a Foddian very well. More rewards like this please! 

The mechanics are deceptively deep for a game about kicking a ball in one direction. There is so much to chew on just kicking the ball, the mechanics all feed into each other and it makes you want to experiment and test the limits of what's possible. 

I can't help but feel these mechanics wouldâ€™ve been better suited to a game that wasn't as punishing as a Foddian. The puzzles are fun but when I have to do the same puzzle for the 50th time instead of seeing the rest of the beautiful game ahead of me, I have to play Limbo and Lust again and again and again. Oh I get it, Hell, cute!

The Training Grounds attempt to remedy this by giving you a chance to practice each individual level outside of an official run of the game, which I like. But why not just let me start from a checkpoint in the actual game? I'm not a speedrunner. I don't care if the run is official or not, I just want to play the game all the way through. I hardly think my run is invalidated whether or not I did it with checkpoints. The game is hard as balls! GIVE ME MY SPIRIT ASHES

Also why do I have to trudge over to the ball every time? Why not have a teleport to the ball location? God knows I know the level well enough after running it 100 times, why do I have to do the walk of shame? If it's just to maximize the negative energy and despair then don't you think you have enough of that already?! ğŸ’€

I know I'm publicly admitting that I'm bad at video game but it feels like Ascending Inferno is too married to being a Foddian where it has such potential to be its own thing. It feels like it wants to stretch its wings but it's held back by expectations of the genre. There's so much competent level design and teaching the player through failure that is wasted on a negative gameplay loop that doesn't give me the motivation to try again. The unique look and pixel art style attracts casual and artistic players who may not be used to the level of punishment that a streamer or speedrunner would be. There are casual players who want to play your game, let them play it.

Ascending Inferno is challenging but it's not too hard intrinsically (as far as I've gotten). In a vacuum; the gameplay is fun and challenging and forces you to think outside your limitations and experiment, but the brutalizing punishment for failure makes it excruciating to learn and grow as a player. If you toned down the punishment with a few checkpoints it would lose its Foddian status but I also think it would make it a dramatically better video game.

A beautiful game with creative level design and deep mechanics that is held back by the constraints of the genre. Spread your wings Ascending Inferno! Miles Morales did his own thing, now it's your turn!

column8: Nunca havia pensado em um jogo de plataforma com futebol e que ainda poderia dar certo e nÃ£o ser sÃ³ extremamente frustrante, mas aqui estÃ¡, nÃ£o sÃ³ o jogo Ã© bom e bem equilibrado em frustraÃ§Ã£o e recompensa ao cair, como a mÃºsica, o cenÃ¡rio e os personagens sÃ£o lindos e interessantes, ele Ã© um jogo que jamais imaginaria e felizmente pude ter contato e me maravilhar com essa junÃ§Ã£o, recomendo muito e usem o controle, usar o teclado pode ser realmente doloroso, mas esse jogo possui um lugar no meu coraÃ§Ã£o.
column9: I had never thought of a platform game with soccer that could still work and not just be extremely frustrating, but here it is, not only is the game good and well balanced in frustration and reward when falling, but the music, the scenery and the characters are beautiful and interesting, it is a game that I never imagined and fortunately I was able to have contact and be amazed by this combination, I highly recommend it and use the controller, using the keyboard can be really painful, but this game has a place in my heart.

column8:
Ascending inferno is a juggler foddian game where you control a character and try to get a ball to the end of the map..
You can dribble the ball automatically when its at your feet, small or hard kick it to go forward, or jump when dribbling to make it go high and then aim yourself to hit the balls with your head.

The map is mostly fair from what i have played, with falls that aren't too punishing, and the only hard ish section i've met so far would be the end of gluttony with the 3 small lamp. Each time you complete a section you also have the opportunity to complete it in the training ground to either practice it or try to get a best time.

Overall, it is a really enjoyable foddian game with unique gameplay.

column8:
Ascending Inferno is a captivating journey into a richly imagined world where tension and intrigue intertwine seamlessly. The author expertly crafts a narrative that grips readers from the very first page, immersing them in a tale that balances the fantastical with the profoundly human.

The characters are well-developed, each bringing their unique strengths and flaws to the table. The protagonist's growth is particularly compelling, as they navigate challenges that test not only their physical abilities but also their moral convictions. The supporting cast adds depth to the story, with each character's arc intricately woven into the larger narrative.

One of the standout features of Ascending Inferno is its vivid world-building. The author paints a detailed picture of the setting, making it easy for readers to visualize and feel a part of the unfolding drama. The plot twists are skillfully executed, keeping the tension high and the reader guessing until the very end.

Additionally, the themes exploredâ€”such as resilience, sacrifice, and the struggle for powerâ€”resonate deeply, prompting readers to reflect on their own experiences. The prose is eloquent yet accessible, striking a perfect balance that enhances the reading experience.

Overall, Ascending Inferno is a masterfully written novel that will appeal to fans of fantasy and adventure alike. Its blend of action, emotion, and moral complexity makes it a standout in the genre. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a gripping and thought-provoking read.

column8: Really tight and challenging gameplay underpinned by positively gorgeous visuals. A really clever evolution on games where "challenge" is the core throughline both thematically and mechanically. Definitely check it out if you enjoy thinking about games while you play them.
column9: Really tight and challenging gameplay underpinned by positively gorgeous visuals. A really clever evolution on games where "challenge" is the core throughline both thematically and mechanically. Definitely check it out if you enjoy thinking about games while you play them.

column8:
Ascending Inferno offers an unforgettable visual journey through a beautifully crafted version of Danteâ€™s Hell. The gameâ€™s voxel art and distinct environments for each layerâ€”like the desolate Limbo or the vibrant nightclub in Lustâ€”are stunningly designed and truly immersive. Apolyon Studioâ€™s attention to detail shines, creating a uniquely rich atmosphere that stands out in the platforming genre. 
This game is frustrating, as intended, but also offers joy and a sense of accomplishment each time you surpass your previous best and progress to each new area and level.

column8:
Great game so far! I love the characters, the art, and also the gameplay, which I might add for anyone scared of it being too frustrating, is way way way less fiddly than it might look. Vincent (da ball) is surprisingly more sticky than I thought he would be, and it saved me a bunch of times.

However, whoever made the second hole in the Lust Level that takes you back down to the end of the First Inferno Level, where if you get really unlucky, can knock you down until you all the way back into the chandelier area. You will be dealt with. Also the ping pong pole dancer demon things. Evil. 

I can't wait until someone speed runs this game so I can live vicariously through them (I assume by this time I will have just finished Greed).

column8:
[REVIEW IN PROGRESS]

I've only played for an hour today and didn't bring a controller, which made it harder on me, but still really appreciating the level of detail that went into the levels. And the devs have found a clever way to MAKE you appreciate them as you'll see each level a few times when you inevitably fumble the ball and have to go fetch it a few levels lower again.

This game is for people with persistence. Now let's find out if I'm one of them...

column8:
Kick your way through the layers of hell?? More like kick your way through the five stages of grief.. 

Denial: It's the game that's bad, not me.
Anger: Okay, I'm bad.. And now I'm mad...
Bargaining: Please just land on the ledge I promise I won't let you fall again...
Depression: Whyyy.... Whyyy did I let you fall again??
Acceptance: Okay, I did it.. I guess I was just trash after all..

This game is a lot of fun, frustrating at times but an awesome twist on the genre. Opened up the game to play for a couple hours and here we are 8 hours later.. The art is beautiful, the music is beautiful. Really awesome to see something different.

Acceptance: Okay, I did it.. I guess I was just trash after all..

This game is a lot of fun, frustrating at times but an awesome twist on the genre. Opened up the game to play for a couple hours and here we are 8 hours later.. The art is beautiful, the music is beautiful. Really awesome to see something different.

column8:
First of all, I love the art in this game. The menus, the cutscenes, the environments are all beautiful and such a vibe. 
The gameplay itself is challenging but also very fun. A piece of my soul dies every time I run back down to the bottom of Lust, but it always feels like this time could be the one I get past that next obstacle. 
The controls feel good! I haven't felt like the controls were unfair or not doing what I want, it's pretty tight all around.
I like the little optional secret rooms, it's nice having a little break to see the characters chat.

Overall: love the game, controls feel good (I use controller), art is very cool and pretty. I definitely recommend for those who enjoy platformers and like a challenge.

column8:
I'm not usually a fan of platforming games since I struggle with the genre, but the love and passion poured into Ascending Inferno really draw me in. The visuals are breathtaking, and there's so much to anticipate as you climb through the depths of hell. The music is incredibly catchy, and the snippets of dialogue between Dani and Vincent motivate me to keep pushing forward to uncover more of their story. Unlike Jump King and Getting Over It, Ascending Inferno feels addictive and offers a refreshing twist on the typical rage game experience.

Congratulations to the dev team on the game's release!

column8:
ğŸš¨TLDR: BUY THIS GAME AND BE PERSISTENT!ğŸš¨

This game is madness! From the incredible and unique art  (or at least, I haven't seen art with such gloss in a game before) to the extra incredible and unique game-concept - absolute madness. 

I love the 7 deadly sins concept for each level. The game play/mechanics are consistent and fair once you spend some time getting used to them. Also there are some hidden mechanics that the tutorial doesn't necessarily show you that make ascending even easier and hype-y like jumping kicks/flicks over your head (I saw a speedrun on youtube with said mechanics that I'm keen to put into practice). That being said, the challenge doesn't necessarily arise from the mechanics (as these play consistently) but decision making - deciding what is the best/safest move to do for each segment/platform - is where the challenge lies.

Also the little garnishes/details (like the customised distance ascended bar for each biome, and a separate camera for the ball) tell me that the devs have put extreme levels of effort and care into making this game. 

I have never really played platformers before, but I am so glad this is my introduction to the genre. AND SO FOR ANYONE ON THE FENCE on whether this game is worth buying/too hard: ABSOLUTELY GIVE IT A TRY. Yes, there are falls but they (at least for me) were part of the fun, and seeing my skills improve even after playing for a short session was extremely satisfying. 

With a little bit of persistence and bravery, I am 120000% sure you will have a fun time (mixed in with times where you feel the full range of human emotions). At the moment, I feel extreme  elation as I have just reached the second level (lust). I will angrily check back in s couple hours if I am still stuck at the same level - or worse: descending back to the start.

column8:
Great art style that combines a modern 2.5D look with gorgeous retro "synthwave" graphics.

The tutorial helps brace the user for the very challenging platforming. The controls are very tight, so overcoming the intense levels is in your hands!

Great storyline and imaginative settings, a great reimagination of Dante's classic.

âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½âš½/10

column8:
Whoever thought 'Sisyphus: The Game' was a good idea owes me a new controller. 

Aside from my inflated frustration ready to rival the Hindenburg, this is a brilliant game. Solid, tight controls, balanced movement, and amazing art & sound design. I've only found a few of the secret spots throughout the game so far, but the story and level design have pushed me through about 99 different "alright, one more go" after a perilous drop. 

I hate it. 10/10.

column8:
I got to play a bit of the game when they were showcasing the game previously, but it's been a while since I last got to play the game for a bit. This game definitely stood out during their showcases :D

Man, this game is makes me want to QUIT every minute of the game I play. 
BUT, it is very pretty. I just finished the Tutorial, Limbo and just got to Lust. There's defs enough incentive to want to keep climbing to get to the different layers of HELL as the areas look different in each section with different mechanics in them. And I do feel like as I keep playing the game, I can get better at it, but also, I believe the game also gets harder and harder as I progress throughout the game.
I also got to the secret room of Limbo :) Make sure to look out for secret rooms with weird satanic looking symbols on them. The secret room is very cool.

column8:
My friends, this wonderful experience is more than a simple game. "Ascending Inferno" is more than just a ball game, more than just a platformer, it is a question that is posed to the player.

"Ascending Inferno" is a masterpiece of visual design, crafted to match the beauty of an immaculately cared for garden. Each platform placed with care, each pit chosen to emphasis the question to the player. Every level being unique but complimentary to the experience. Each soundtrack being a complimentary masterful composition that tells you the story of this place.

I am drawn in and repeatedly posed the question. But what truly makes this game stand above all others is its ability to tap into the essence of this exact question. It allows for yourself and others to experience the world. It lets you celebrate your hard earned achievements where only one small miscalculation, one small miskick, one wrong input can easily undo your progress.

The hellish environment becomes a backdrop as you slowly progress, learning the exact position you must be on, the exact movement that is required to progress. You become Dani, and Dani becomes you. Knowing her ability to influence the world is mastery to answering the question.

So what is this question, you may be asking dear friends? What is this question that this masterful art piece poses to us, the players of this game?
Is it a question about life and death? Is it a question about success being a fine line from failure? Is it a question about relationships and connection?

Such a question cannot actually be expressed through the medium of words, for such a question can only be posed to the player through their own discovery.

This game will leave the player frustrated at their own actions, knowing every mistake is of their own doing. But in this way it also means that the satisfaction of success is also through the players own doing.

column8:
About the same difficulty as real-life soccer. âš½

EDIT: Okay, now that I've played for a couple hours, here's a legitimate review.

Ascending Inferno is certainly not for the faint of heart. If you're looking for a casual platformer that's approachable, forgiving, and with plenty of checkpoints, look elsewhere. But if you thrive off challenge, precision, and are seeking a unique platformer that's oozing with style, this is the perfect game to add to your library.

The gameplay is incredibly straightforward: progress upwards through a variety of platforming challenges to escape Inferno. However, this has to be done all whilst juggling a sentient soccer ball (who also happens to be your brother?) by using your own physics to ensure the ball ascends with you.

The catch? The ball can fall. Way down. Aaaaaaall the way down to the start of the level. Sometimes even back to a previous level if you're unlucky.

While this is tedious, it's also the perfect opportunity to hone your skills. You'll be repeatedly climbing and falling through particularly difficult sections of each level to the point where you become incredibly confident and most previous areas are a breeze. It's a strangely satisfying yet punishing difficulty curve.

This is massively enhanced by atmosphere which is dripping in Hellish style, combining stunning pixel and voxel art with neon lighting to produce backgrounds that put even Castlevania to shame. While I'm only in the second level of Inferno, Lust, I'm already blown away by the game's visual style and can't wait to see what's ahead (if I can make it that far!).

Overall, this is a game that those who embrace difficulty and challenge will truly resonate with. If you're a skilled platformer enthusiast, give it a go and put your skills to the test as you attempt (and your soccer ball) attempt to escape inferno.

column8:
I havenâ€™t even been able to get past the second floor of this game and still it is the best game of its ilk. Itâ€™s more demanding of the player and more visually unique and exciting.

Where Only Up, Chained Together and even Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy are arguable asset flips, Ascending Inferno is thoughtfully designed in environments and obstacles. Itâ€™ll charm you endlessly even when you plummet further into the depths of the underworld in your attempted ascent out.
